header.title: Class 24 – Multiple Signifiers
authors: Esoteric School of Shamanism and Magic
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Tarot Reading, Divination, Magical Practice

central_thesis: This system provides advanced Tarot techniques for detailed analysis of complex situations, relationships, and magical effects by employing multiple, spatially arranged signifier cards and iterative 'expanded readings' to uncover nuanced influences and hidden magical workings.

structure_content.summary: This section notes that preparation for the class includes reviewing video clips on multiple signifiers.

This chapter introduces the concept of using more than one card, or alternative symbols, as signifiers to represent intricate situations, persons, or relationships in Tarot readings. It emphasizes that the physical positioning of these signifier cards (e.g., on top and to the right) directly determines the nature of their influence within the reading. The text advises using as few Tarot cards as possible for signifiers to preserve the deck for the actual reading content.

This section details the method for using two-card signifiers to explore the relationship between two entities (e.g., two people, a person and a situation, or aspects of oneself). The first card is placed in a normal position, and the second card is positioned on top and to the right of the first, signifying its effect. Each signifier card must be 'keyed' individually. The chapter explains the utility of performing a 'base reading' on the first signifier before adding the second, allowing for the identification of new factors or lines created by the second signifier's influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: 4. Using Three or More Card Signifiers
structure_content.summary: This chapter expands on the signifier technique for highly complex situations, describing how to use three or more cards. It illustrates this with an example involving career, self, and family, where cards are layered sequentially (e.g., 8 Discs for career, then self signifier on top/right, then 3 Cups for family on top/right of self). Each new signifier requires an additional reading pass to reveal its specific influence. A different layout is presented for analyzing the effect of two people on a relationship, with the relationship signifier at the bottom and person signifiers to its left and right. The text also mentions square patterns for four or more factors, stressing that signifiers should be built vertically or to the left to avoid misinterpreting a sequence of effect, and reiterates the importance of using minimal Tarot cards for signifiers.

This section introduces a specialized technique to magnify specific card stacks from an existing Celtic Cross or 12 Card reading for deeper insight. The process involves selecting a problematic stack of cards, placing it as a signifier on the reading plate (typically on top and to the right of the original signifier), and then performing a new 12 Card reading based on this 'blown-up' stack. The timeline of this expanded reading corresponds to the original stack's position within the initial reading. A significant application is 'spell tracking,' where specific reversed Tarot cards (e.g., Magi Rx, Priestess Rx, 7 Swords Rx, Chariot Rx, Devil Rx) in the original reading can indicate an adverse magical spell, which can then be investigated through multiple levels of expanded readings to identify the spell's nature or origin.
This chapter specifies the phrase 'In Beauty.' as the designated mantra for this week's Exit Ritual, Day Greetings, and Day Endings (across six directions).

key_concepts.definition: The practice of using more than one Tarot card, or other symbolic representations, in a specific arrangement to represent a complex person, situation, or relationship as the focus for a detailed divination reading.

The precise spatial arrangement of multiple signifier cards (e.g., on top and to the right of another card) which dictates the interpretative relationship and causal effect within the reading, where cards 'on top and to the right' affect those 'below'.
An initial Tarot reading performed with a single signifier to establish foundational factors and context, prior to the introduction of additional signifiers for comparative and layered analysis.

The ritualistic act of intentionally associating a specific card or symbol with a particular person, concept, or situation, thereby consecrating its role as a signifier for the reading. This must be done individually for each signifier.

An advanced divination technique where a specific stack or pair of cards from an initial Tarot reading is removed, designated as a new signifier, and then used to perform a subsequent, more detailed 12 Card reading. This process allows for an in-depth exploration of the factors related to that specific card stack.

A practical application of expanded readings, used to identify and diagnose hidden adverse magical spells or energetic blockages that may be indicated by specific reversed Major Arcana cards (e.g., Magi Rx, Priestess Rx) within an original Tarot reading. This process may require multiple layers of expanded readings.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is an advanced Tarot divination methodology based on 'multiple signifiers'. It involves constructing signifiers using two or more Tarot cards (or other symbols) arranged in specific spatial relationships (e.g., on top and to the right) to represent complex interactions, influences, or relationships. Each signifier must be 'keyed' individually. Readings are often iterative, starting with a base reading and adding signifiers sequentially to observe new factors. The system includes 'Expanded or Blow-Up Readings' where a stack of cards from an initial reading becomes a signifier for a new, in-depth reading, particularly useful for diagnosing hidden magical spells or gaining granular detail from specific energetic dynamics. The text provides a ritualistic phrase for daily practice.
tools: Candles (for lighting and extinguishing during readings)
Alternative signifiers (pictures, symbols, lists, cutout shapes, written descriptions)
rituals: Exit Ritual: 'In Beauty.' (for Day Greetings and Day Endings, 6 directions)

relevant_quotes.text: You can use more than one card in your signifier to specify in detail any situation, person or relationship you want to read. These are called multiple signifiers.
The position of a card or item in the signifier layout determines the effect it has on the reading. Cards on top of and to the right of other cards are affecting the cards below.
Blow-up readings are useful for tracking hidden adverse magical spells that people have done – these almost always show up in readings.
If the spell was created by a very skilled practitioner you may need to expand the reading 6 or 8 times to find the actual spell.

critical_analysis.relevance: This system offers a highly relevant and sophisticated approach to Tarot divination, pushing beyond simplistic interpretations to provide granular insight into complex causal relationships and energetic dynamics. By systematizing the use of multiple signifiers and iterative 'blow-up' readings, it equips practitioners with a potent tool for deep analysis, self-reflection, relationship assessment, and the diagnosis of subtle magical influences or adverse spells. It bridges divinatory practice with an operative magical framework, allowing for a more active engagement with the insights gained.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this text is experienced Tarot readers and practitioners of Western Esotericism and practical magic. It presumes a foundational understanding of basic Tarot layouts (Celtic Cross, 12 Card Reading), the concept of signifiers, and a desire to engage with advanced, technically precise methods for divination and magical diagnosis. This work is particularly valuable for those seeking to understand and potentially intervene in complex energetic or magical situations.
